title: Granddad broke both arms on holiday and died on journey home
text:
Louis ‘Reg’ Belcourt, 75, slipped on a wet floor while walking and fell shortly after arriving in Mauritius for a family holiday (Picture: BPM)

A grandfather of 13 died while on his way back to the UK after breaking both his arms on a family holiday.

Louis ‘Reg’ Belcourt, 75, slipped on a wet floor while walking shortly after arriving in Mauritius.

He died before he managed to get home after suffering breathing complications as a result of surgery to fix his broken bones, his inquest heard.

The ex-town councillor in Hythe, Kent, was told he would need surgery to both his shoulders after his dangerous fall on 28 May.

After his second surgery on 1 June, Mr Belcourt developed complications and when his stepdaughter, Stephanie Belcourt, spoke on the phone to him three days later, she realised he was suffering from postoperative delirium.

Mr Belcourt had to be ventilated and intubated as he suffered from progressive respiratory failure after the extensive surgery.

His family flew out to Mauritius to be with him and decided he should be flown home to the UK for treatment.

Mr Belcourt was transported on 15 June but had to make a stop in Nuremberg to change crews.

Stephanie told the inquest that medics at the hospital in Mauritius had been concerned that prolonged intubation may lead to infection or further complications.

She said: ‘They said the longer he was left there, the more liable he is for infection.’

‘What they feared would happen did happen.’

Mr Belcourt was a town councillor in Hythe, Kent, for 15 years (Picture: BPM)

During the descent to Nuremberg, Mr Belcourt experienced a significant drop in tidal volume – which is the volume of air displaced between normal inhalation and exhalation.

Resuscitation efforts began as the plane was landing, while emergency services were called to the tarmac.

An ambulance was waiting at the airport, where further resuscitation efforts took place, but Mr Belcourt was declared dead.

A post mortem examination found the cause of death to be cardiomegaly – an abnormal enlargement of the heart which may have prevented it from pumping properly.

Mr Belcourt’s prolonged exposure to ventilation and high temperature led the pathologist to believe that this was in combination with sepsis, the inquest heard.

The fractures Mr Belcourt sustained and the subsequent ventilation was recorded as a secondary cause of death.

Assistant coroner Catherine Wood recorded a narrative conclusion due to the complex cause of death.

She said: ‘He died as a consequence of prolonged ventilation following surgery for fractures from a fall.’
